dialogues.text: We're now in a grimy little room with an airshaft view. Young Joan is sitting on the lumpy bed, crying her eyes o while Young Joe calmly inspects the hot plate.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG JOAN
dialogues.text: I can't stay here! It's filthy! This is a room for an alcoholic!

dialogues.text: Look, if you don't want to be here, then go back to Smith. I'm sure they'll take you back with open arms. You were victimized, after all -- the lovely young debutante raped by the oversexed Jewish professor.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG JOAN
dialogues.text: I'm not a debutante! Screw you, Joe! I knew exactly what I was doing!

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG JOE
dialogues.text: I'm not your adoring mentor anymore, my girl. I'm now officially a struggling writer who has yet to write his first legitimate novel. We could be living like this for a very long time. If you can’t take it, I understand. It would break my heart, but if you can't take this life, then I release you. Go, I release you, go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We see Joan carrying her suitcase down the stairs to the street. She stops at the bottom of the stairway where there’s a grimy mirror. She stops and takes a look at herself: she’s wearing one of her nice traveling outfits a pair of white ladylike gloves and she has to admit that does indeed look like a nice ex-debutante. This infuriate her. She peels off her gloves and flings them to the floo then marches back up the stairs, dragging her suitcase.  23

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joan has returned. She's now standing at the open door of their tiny room, gazing at Joe, who's hunched over the ta he’s made into his desk. He has a note pad beside him wit few scribbles on it and he’s staring at the empty page in typewriter, his heart too broken to write. Joe turns and looks at her with his beautiful, haunted ey

dialogues.text: I love you, Joe. I believe in you. I believe in you with all my heart. Joe looks like he's going to weep. Joan goes to him and h pulls her onto his lap and buries his face in her neck.

dialogues.text: We see Joe and Joan buried under the giant eiderdown fast asleep. We hear the gentle rustle of the drapes being pul open. A cool light pours over them. More rustling, soft footsteps, whispers...and suddenly we hear a chorus of gi break into song. Joe and Joan lurch out of their deep traveler's sleep and stare groggily up at a circle of angelic-looking SWEDISH GIRLS in white robes who are standing around their bed holding candles and singing some indecipherable Swedish s of celebration. Joan and Joe, disoriented, sit up and groggily stare at t crowd in their room. Walter is standing by.

dialogues.speaker: WALTER
dialogues.text: Good morning Mr. Castleman. Today is St. Lucia day and this is St. Lucia who has come to pay her respect to a great writer.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: St. Lucia...

dialogues.speaker: WALTER

dialogues.speaker: JOE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: This looks wonderful. Thank you. Linnea is there. She crouches down by the bed and starts taking pictures. Joan, feeling puffy and unattractive, wo rather she not.

dialogues.speaker: JOAN
dialogues.text: (slipping out if bed) Excuse me...

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: Where’re you going?

dialogues.speaker: JOAN
dialogues.text: I'd like to freshen up. Joan goes into the bathroom and shuts the door.

dialogues.speaker: WALTER
dialogues.text: I’m so sorry, Mr. Castleman, is this an inconvenience?

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: No, no, I’m grateful that you woke me up. I was in the middle of a nightmare. JI was back in Brooklyn, still living with my mother. He gets a laugh. Joe takes a big bite of a pastry. Crumbs tumble onto the sheets.

dialogues.speaker: JOE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Delicious! This is fantastic.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joan has shut the door and is hunched on the toilet, havi one of those endless morning pees. She can hear the girls serenading Joe through the door. She starts to shiver uncontrollably. To calm herself, she starts quietly singi her own little song.

dialogues.speaker: JOAN
dialogues.text: I’m Mrs. Joseph Castleman, Oh lucky, lucky me, His brilliance shines through my soul, even when I pee.  24 THE WIFE FINAL SHOOTING SCRIPT (16/12/16) 38.

dialogues.text: We're at a formal reception that's set up with a vast buf of food and SERVERS circulating with trays of champagne. Joe, with a plate of food in his hands, is regaling a gro of NOTABLE SWEDES with one of his standard anecdotes.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: ...my father was a shoe salesman. He died of a heart attack when I was seven while he was fitting some pimply kid with a pair of saddle shoes. dialogues.speaker: JOE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: So when I come home from school that day, my mother grabs me, presses me to her substantial bosom and says, "Joe, I have something terrible to tell you." Before she can get it out, my tiny Russian grandmother, who's built like a footstool, screams at her, "not before dinner, you'll ruin his appetite!" The English speakers laugh. He d so and Joan gives him a little nod that it’s gone.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Have you ever thought of letting him leave in the crumbs?

dialogues.text: Married people don’t do that, Darling. Our job is to protect each other from humiliation. Arvid comes over.

dialogues.text: Excuse me, I hate to interrupt this wonderful exchange, but I’d like to introduce the Castlemans to another one of our laureate families.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: Of course.

dialogues.text: (to Joe) James Finch is getting our prize in physics. A very brilliant man and nice as can be.

dialogues.text: Terrific, can’t wait to meet him. Arvid ushers Joe, Joan and David over to JAMES FINCH who’ standing with his wife CONSTANCE and the four FINCH CHILD (aged 15 to 25).

dialogues.text: James Finch, may I introduce you to the novelist Joseph Castleman. James, an Englishman and an alpha male like Joe shakes ha with him.

dialogues.text: Pleasure to meet you. I wish I could say that I've read all your books.

dialogues.text: Please, I wish I could say that I understand your formulas. Laughter. Finch’s wife Constance, a jolly, toothy lady sh hands with Joe.

dialogues.text: I've read your books, and I promise you, they're a much better read than James's scribblings.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES FINCH
dialogues.text: My wife Constance is a scientist as well, and as you can see, she's quite critical of my work.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: Well, my wife doesn't write, thank God, otherwise I'd have permanent writer's block. More laughter. Joan extends her hand and introduces herse

dialogues.speaker: JOAN
dialogues.text: Hello, I'm Joan.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: Joan is the light of my life.  THE WIFE FINAL SHOOTING SCRIPT (16/12/16) 40.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES FINCH
dialogues.text: Let me introduce you to my children -- this is Peter, Sam, Ellen, Chester... The Finch kids, a cheerful, outgoing lot, say hello to th Castlemans and shake their hands. David is itching for a cigarette.

dialogues.speaker: ARVID ENGDAHL
dialogues.text: If I may brag for James for a moment -- his children are all quite remarkable. Ellen is doing work on the metabolism of neural cells, is that right?

dialogues.speaker: JAMES FINCH
dialogues.text: Yes, I'm counting on her to find the cure to Alzheimer's just in time for my own dementia. Lots of good-natured chuckling. ELLEN FINCH, a socially awkward 19-year-old rolls her eyes to David, trying to bo with him.

dialogues.text: Tell them please about your children’s other wonderfl studies!

dialogues.text: Sam here is working in conductive polymers. Peter is interested in prime factors. And Chester is trying to disprove the string theory -- he’s a bit out of his league but we indulge him. James ruffles his brilliant son's hair.

dialogues.speaker: JOAN
dialogues.text: Well aren’t you a bunch of bright pennies.

dialogues.text: David is a writer. He's developing quite a voice. Walter comes over.

dialogues.speaker: WALTER

dialogues.speaker: JOAN

dialogues.text: And next time, don't refer to me as your son, the half-baked writer.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: I grew up hard, my friend. Live a little and let's see what you come up with. David gets out his cigarettes.

dialogues.text: If only. FADE OUT.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joan, up and dressed for the day, is sitting in an arm ch staring at Joe who’s fast asleep under the eiderdown. Her face is unreadable. There’s a knock on the door. She gets up and goes down th hall and lets in the ROOM SERVICE SERVER who’s pushing a elegantly set with breakfast.

dialogues.speaker: JOAN
dialogues.text: Mr. Castleman will have that in the library, thank you. We FOLLOW Joan back to the bedroom where she gives Joe a little shake.

dialogues.speaker: JOAN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Joe...

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: Mmm?

dialogues.speaker: JOAN
dialogues.text: You need to get up. They’re picking you up in forty minutes.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: Jesus...all right, I’m getting up.

dialogues.speaker: JOAN
dialogues.text: Your lunch is here. Here’re your extra reading glasses. And here are your pills.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: You’re not coming with me?

dialogues.speaker: JOAN
dialogues.text: I'd like some time to myself.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: To do what?  34 THE WIFE FINAL SHOOTING SCRIPT (16/12/16) 53.

dialogues.speaker: JOAN
dialogues.text: I don't know, maybe I'll take a tour of the city.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: On some lousy tourist bus?

dialogues.speaker: JOAN
dialogues.text: Joe, please. I'll be in a much better mood if you let me go.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: I just thought this was something we should be doing together. Joan sets down Joe’s heart pills.

dialogues.speaker: JOAN
dialogues.text: You need to take one of these at three. I’m setting the alarm on your watch. Joan puts Joe’s watch back on his bedside table and leave

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joan, freed of Joe's celebrity, is taking her own sweet t walking through the lobby. No one is bowing and scraping, one is taking pictures, no one is hovering with awe in th eyes...

dialogues.speaker: BONE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Mrs. Castleman... Joan turns and sees Nathanial getting up from one of the elegant sitting areas. He has a newspaper tucked under hi arm.

dialogues.speaker: JOAN
dialogues.text: Nathanial.

dialogues.speaker: BONE
dialogues.text: I’m not stalking you, I promise. But I have something for you -- I was going to leave it for you at the desk... Bone pulls out an envelope and hands it to Joan.

dialogues.speaker: BONE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I found it at a bookstore at Smith when I was doing research on Joe.  35
Joan pulls out a hand-tinted post card, circa 1927, of so young college women doing a skit, the caption: Northrop H Follies, Smith College.

dialogues.speaker: JOAN
dialogues.text: Oh, Northrop House. That was my dorm.

dialogues.speaker: BONE
dialogues.text: I know. The picture's a bit before your time, but I thought you'd get a kick out of it. Joan is impressed by the gift but doesn't entirely trust Bone.

dialogues.speaker: JOAN
dialogues.text: Thank you, Nathanial, this was very thoughtful.

dialogues.speaker: BONE
dialogues.text: Well, you've always been very kind to me during my aborted attempts to woo Joe. Listen, there’s a great bar here, very nineteenth century. You can imagine Strinberg getting hammered there. Can I buy you a drink?

dialogues.speaker: JOAN
dialogues.text: Oh, I don't know how appropriate that would be.

dialogues.speaker: BONE
dialogues.text: It’s completely inappropriate. But we're in Sweden in the dead of winter and I don’t think either of us should be left alone to our own brooding thoughts, do you? Bone is actually flirting with her. Joan finds it rather enjoyable. Joe would be appalled. And that’s why she says...

dialogues.speaker: JOAN
dialogues.text: One drink. No more.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 35 Joan and Bone are now sitting in a quaint, wood panelled tavern. It's a cozy, intimate place, good for losing one' sobriety. They're both having icy, vodka-based drinks.

dialogues.speaker: BONE
dialogues.text: ..-listen, I want you to know that I’ve gotten an offer to write a book about Joe. I wanted to tell you so you don’t think I’m doing anything behind his back.

dialogues.speaker: JOAN
dialogues.text: And is this going to be a scholarly work?

dialogues.speaker: BONE
dialogues.text: Yes and no.

dialogues.speaker: JOAN
dialogues.text: Meaning what?

dialogues.speaker: BONE
dialogues.text: Please don't take offense, but you might as well know that I'm aware of Joe's various indiscretions.

dialogues.speaker: JOAN
dialogues.text: (unruf fled) I'm sure you are. I imagine it's all very juicy material for a biographer.

dialogues.speaker: BONE
dialogues.text: To be honest, it's a little predictable. Most of your men of genius seem to have overactive libidos. And thanks to the worshipful tomes put out by us biographers, we're supposed to find it all very charming and forgivable. I don't, actually. I think that kind of behavior is rather appalling.

dialogues.speaker: JOAN
dialogues.text: Please don't paint me as a victim. I'm much more interesting than that.

dialogues.speaker: BONE
dialogues.text: Oh, I know you are. Look, I don’t want to make the wrong assumptions about your relationship. So why don't you set me straight?

dialogues.speaker: JOAN
dialogues.text: Oh Nathanial, you're so trans- parent. I can't believe I let you lure me here.  36 THE WIFE FINAL SHOOTING SCRIPT (16/12/16) 56.

dialogues.speaker: BONE
dialogues.text: Of course you're free to get up and leave this cozy cafe and these excellent drinks and spend the rest of the afternoon in some drafty museum of obscure Nordic art. Joan takes a careful sip of her drink.

dialogues.speaker: JOAN
dialogues.text: All right. You have an hour with me.

dialogues.speaker: BONE
dialogues.text: Thank you, Joan. I really do appreciate this. And if there's anything you don't want to talk about, feel free to tell me to fuck off.

dialogues.speaker: JOAN
dialogues.text: Oh, don't worry, I will.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're on stage where WORKMEN are arranging giant stands o flowers to frame the ceremony. A TELEVISION CREW is setti up for the broadcast. James Finch and the other LAUREATES are gathered on stage a rehearsal. They’re all chatting amicably among themselv while the NOBEL ORGANIZERS and ASSISTANTS stand on the sidelines, watching them in delight. Joe arrives with Walter in tow.

dialogues.speaker: WALTER
dialogues.text: Mister Castleman, let me introduce you to your fellow laureates. Gentlemen, this is Joseph Castleman who is to receive the Nobel Prize in literature. The other laureates pause in their conversations and turn Joe. They all shake hands as they’re introduced. WALTER (CONT’D) Professor Finch, you have already met...this is Professor Chen Ling who's receiving the prize in chemistry...Doctor Karl Seigler, our esteemed laureate in medicine...and Sir Randall Meade who's receiving the prize in economics.  THE WIFE FINAL SHOOTING SCRIPT (16/12/16) 57. Joe, intimidated by all this brilliance, is grinning and hunting around for something pithy to say.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: Well, to quote Groucho Marx, “I never want to be a member of a club that would have me.” However, with this crowd I’d be an idiot not to make an exception. Hearty laughter from the great men. Linnea is there with her camera. She takes a few quick sh to capture this moment, then gives Joe a wink.

dialogues.speaker: WALTER
dialogues.text: I will turn you over to Mr. Lagerfelt who will instruct you on the protocol for tomorrow’s ceremony. The impeccable MR. LAGERFELT steps forward.

dialogues.speaker: MR. LAGERFELT
dialogues.text: Gentlemen, you will be entering from this side of the stage, in this order: Sir Meade, Professor Finch, Mr.Castleman, Professor Ling and Doctor Seigler. You will take your seats here, indicated, for now, by these signs with your names. When it is your time to receive your medal, you will walk from your seat, to here. And you will receive your medal from the King. Mr. Lagerfelt demonstrates with an OLDER GENTLEMAN who’s standing in for the king and gives him the medal box. MR. LAGERFELT (CONT’D) You shall then bow, making the three reverences. Like so. We will start with you Mr. Castleman. Joe, feeling the other laureates’ eyes on him, can’t focu

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: I’m sorry -- do I bow first?

dialogues.speaker: MR. LAGERFELT
dialogues.text: You approach the king and then you bow.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: Ah -- sorry.  THE WIFE FINAL SHOOTING SCRIPT (16/12/16) 58.

dialogues.speaker: MR. LAGERFELT
dialogues.text: No need to apologize. That is why we are practicing.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES FINCH
dialogues.text: It’s not rocket science, Castleman! The other laureates chuckle good-naturedly but Joe grimac bit. He approaches the gentleman playing the king who han him a stand-in for the box with the Nobel medal. Linnea i clicking away, her camera feeling a little too close.

dialogues.speaker: MR. LAGERFELT
dialogues.text: And now the three reverences. Joe awkwardly bows in the three directions as Linnea continues to take her shots -- click...click...click.... MR. LAGERFELT (CONT’D) Very good Mr. Castleman, you may now return to your seat. Joe is sweating.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: If you'll excuse me for a moment...

dialogues.speaker: WALTER
dialogues.text: (hovering) Are you feeling all right, Mr. Castleman?

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: I just need to take a break, excuse me.

dialogues.speaker: WALTER
dialogues.text: Can I bring you some water?

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: I'm fine, I’m fine. Thank you. Carry on! Joe walks off the stage.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bone is getting out his cigarettes -- foreign, of course. offers one to Joan.

dialogues.speaker: BONE
dialogues.text: Do you smoke?

dialogues.speaker: JOAN
dialogues.text: Not officially.  THE WIFE FINAL SHOOTING SCRIPT (16/12/16) 59.

dialogues.speaker: BONE
dialogues.text: I would guess that Joe made you give it up.

dialogues.speaker: JOAN
dialogues.text: Yes, he wants to keep me healthy. Joan takes a cigarette. Bone lights it for her. There’s a hint of seduction in the gesture. Bone pulls out a notebook.

dialogues.speaker: BONE
dialogues.text: May I?

dialogues.speaker: JOAN
dialogues.text: Go ahead.

dialogues.speaker: BONE
dialogues.text: First fascinating query -- this is the publisher's not mine: "What does the Nobel Prize mean to Joseph Castleman?"

dialogues.speaker: JOAN
dialogues.text: Oh God.

dialogues.speaker: BONE
dialogues.text: What if I just quote what he said to me on the plane, "it's not about the prize, it's about getting up the gumption to write the next book."

dialogues.speaker: JOAN
dialogues.text: Perfect. Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: BONE
dialogues.text: And what about you? How do you get up the gumption?

dialogues.speaker: JOAN
dialogues.text: To get up in the morning?

dialogues.speaker: BONE
dialogues.text: To write.

dialogues.speaker: JOAN
dialogues.text: I'm not a writer, Nathanial.

dialogues.speaker: BONE
dialogues.text: I beg to differ. When I was looking through the Smith archives I found some of your stories that were published in the college journal. I read "The Faculty Wife." It’s a beautifully written piece.  THE WIFE FINAL SHOOTING SCRIPT (16/12/16) 60.

dialogues.speaker: JOAN
dialogues.text: Thank you, but the fact is I had potential and nothing more.

dialogues.speaker: BONE
dialogues.text: And you don't regret giving it up?

dialogues.speaker: JOAN
dialogues.text: No, I had very low expectations of what I could accomplish as a female writer.

dialogues.speaker: BONE
dialogues.text: But there were plenty of successful women writers back then.

dialogues.speaker: JOAN
dialogues.text: A few. But I didn’t have the right personality for it.

dialogues.speaker: BONE
dialogues.text: Really.

dialogues.speaker: JOAN
dialogues.text: I’m quite shy. I don’t like to be looked at.

dialogues.speaker: BONE
dialogues.text: All right, I won’t look at you.

dialogues.speaker: JOAN
dialogues.text: How kind. Joan takes a sip of her drink.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: Did Joe encourage you to keep writing?

dialogues.speaker: JOAN
dialogues.text: Yes, but as I said, I didn't choose to pursue it.

dialogues.speaker: BONE
dialogues.text: Because he was the writer of the family.

dialogues.speaker: JOAN
dialogues.text: Now Nathanial, if you’re trolling for nuggets of bitterness you'll find none here.

dialogues.speaker: BONE
dialogues.text: Speaking of bitterness, I've talked to his ex, Carol.

dialogues.speaker: JOAN
dialogues.text: How is she doing?  THE WIFE FINAL SHOOTING SCRIPT (16/12/16) 61.

dialogues.speaker: BONE
dialogues.text: She's a psychiatrist.

dialogues.speaker: JOAN
dialogues.text: Oh. Good for her. And their daughter, Fanny?

dialogues.speaker: BONE
dialogues.text: She's a dentist. Carol forgives you, by the way.

dialogues.speaker: JOAN
dialogues.text: I'm glad. Joe tried to keep in contact with them...I urged him to. We both feel very badly about that chapter of our lives.

dialogues.speaker: BONE
dialogues.text: She said to thank you for taking him off her hands.

dialogues.speaker: JOAN
dialogues.text: She’s welcome. Joan takes a drag of her cigarette, taps the ash. Bone is watching her.

dialogues.speaker: BONE
dialogues.text: I hope you know that Joe’s affairs don’t have anything to do with you. It’s a compulsion. I believe it’s a part of his deep-seated fear of inadequacy.

dialogues.speaker: JOAN
dialogues.text: Well, aren't you the therapist.

dialogues.speaker: BONE
dialogues.text: Do you have anyone that you confide in?

dialogues.speaker: JOAN
dialogues.text: No. But I don't really care to.

dialogues.speaker: BONE
dialogues.text: And that's what makes you so attractive. Your mystery.

dialogues.speaker: JOAN
dialogues.text: My God, Nathanial, are you flirting with me?

dialogues.speaker: BONE
dialogues.text: Oh, probably. Why not?

dialogues.speaker: JOAN
dialogues.text: You know I don't trust you.  38 THE WIFE FINAL SHOOTING SCRIPT (16/12/16) 62.

dialogues.speaker: BONE
dialogues.text: Of course you don't. I'ma writer on a deadline, why should you? The waiter comes by and sets down a little plate of Swedi meatballs.

dialogues.speaker: BONE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Would you like another drink?

dialogues.speaker: JOAN
dialogues.text: One is my limit, thank you.

dialogues.speaker: BONE
dialogues.text: Oh come on. I’m having another.

dialogues.speaker: JOAN
dialogues.text: No, Nathanial. Nathanial signals to the waiter to bring two more.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joe has wandered into a formal, re-carpeted chamber that surrounded on all sides by doors and mirrors. He looks around it, disorientated.

dialogues.speaker: LINNEA, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Mr. Castleman? Joe turns and sees Linnea. She holds her hands up to show that she doesn’t have her cameras with her. LINNEA (CONT’D) I come to you unarmed. I could see that I was getting on your nerves. All that clicking in your face. I do apologize.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: No apologies necessary, it’s your job.

dialogues.speaker: LINNEA
dialogues.text: They told me that if you wish, they will release you for the day.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: I wish that, yes. (looking at all the doors) Which one of these offers the quickest escape?

dialogues.speaker: LINNEA
dialogues.text: Shall we try them and see? There my be a secret passageway.  THE WIFE FINAL SHOOTING SCRIPT (16/12/16) 63.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: Or a dead end.

dialogues.speaker: LINNEA
dialogues.text: We must choose carefully.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: Indeed. They stand there together, playing this little game, the sexual tension between them palpable.

dialogues.speaker: LINNEA
dialogues.text: May I confess something.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: Go ahead.

dialogues.speaker: LINNEA
dialogues.text: I am usually very objective about my subjects. But you move me. Very much.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: Do I.

dialogues.speaker: LINNEA
dialogues.text: You have a wonderful face. Linnea cups Joe’s head in her hands and peers into his fa eyes shining. She touches his strong, high brow, the line on his forehead, evidence of all that genius... LINNEA (CONT’D) Your mind...where does it all come from? Joe can see that she wants to be kissed. How can he resis her luscious young lips or the comforting territory of a young acolyte’s ass. BEE-BEE, BEE-BEE. The alarm on Joe's watch has gone off.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: Oh shit. He starts fiddling with his watch, trying to turn it off.

dialogues.speaker: JOE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Shit. My pills.

dialogues.speaker: LINNEA
dialogues.text: Your pills?

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: For my blood pressure.  THE WIFE FINAL SHOOTING SCRIPT (16/12/16) 64.

dialogues.speaker: LINNEA
dialogues.text: Do you need to take them?

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: I think I should head back to the hotel.

dialogues.speaker: LINNEA
dialogues.text: Yes, all right. Joe is dying. He wants to get out of there. He pulls a walnut out of his pocket and offers it up to her.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: Here -- Joe gets out a pen and starts writing on it.

dialogues.speaker: JOE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: To Linnea -- that's L-I-N-E-A..

dialogues.speaker: LINNEA
dialogues.text: No, two N's.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: Two N's. Joe tries to rub the letters out.

dialogues.speaker: LINNEA
dialogues.text: That’s all right -- I should go. Do you know the way out?

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: Yes. I’m fine. Go ahead. Linnea makes a hasty exit, leaving Joe holding the walnut feeling like an utter fool.

dialogues.speaker: JOE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Aw shit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joan has made a healthy dent in her second drink. She and Bone are lighting up another cigarette.

dialogues.speaker: BONE
dialogues.text: You know, I'm curious about something. Off the record.

dialogues.speaker: JOAN
dialogues.text: Off the record -- we’ve all heard that one before.

dialogues.speaker: BONE
dialogues.text: On my honor.  THE WIFE FINAL SHOOTING SCRIPT (16/12/16) 65. Bone puts his note pad down.

dialogues.speaker: BONE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I've read some of Joe's early work - - some short stories I dug up ina couple of obscure literary journals. I hate to say it, but they weren't so great.

dialogues.speaker: JOAN
dialogues.text: Early work is rarely very readable, I think you know that.

dialogues.speaker: BONE
dialogues.text: But there isn't even a hint of his mature voice. In fact your piece, "The Faculty Wife" reads more like early Castleman than these do.

dialogues.speaker: JOAN
dialogues.text: That doesn’t surprise me. Joe had a very heavy hand as a teacher.

dialogues.speaker: BONE
dialogues.text: Fair enough, but when I talked to Carol, she said it was odd how his writing got so much better after he met you.

dialogues.speaker: JOAN
dialogues.text: That’s very generous of her.

dialogues.speaker: BONE
dialogues.text: With all respect, I think you're tired of his affairs, tired of being invisible, tired of putting your enormous talent into creating the Castleman legend. And for the health of your family, this might be something you'd want to do. David seems like a very unhappy young man.

dialogues.speaker: JOAN
dialogues.text: You have no business talking about my children.

dialogues.speaker: BONE
dialogues.text: No, you’re right. I apologize. (gently) I think you really do want to talk. And I give you my word, I'll never reveal my source. I’1ll be the bad guy so you don’t have to feel like you're betraying Joe. The truth will be out and then you'd be free to write on your own.  40 THE WIFE FINAL SHOOTING SCRIPT (16/12/16) 66.

dialogues.speaker: JOAN
dialogues.text: What a marvelous story, Nathaniel. You really ought to write fiction. Joan gets up.

dialogues.speaker: BONE
dialogues.text: You know where to find me. And Joan, I want you to know -- I really do enjoy your company. Joan gives Bone one of her gracious, elusive smiles and s leaves him there to stew over his drink.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joan, looking rattled, is now letting herself into the su We hear Joe calling.

dialogues.speaker: JOE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Joan?! Joanie ?! Is that you?!

dialogues.speaker: JOAN
dialogues.text: Yes. Joe appears, half-dressed in his boxer shorts and dress shirt.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: Where have you been? I've been worried sick.

dialogues.speaker: JOAN
dialogues.text: Joe, it's only four-thirty.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: But look how dark it is already! Don't do this to me, don't disappear on me like that.

dialogues.speaker: JOAN
dialogues.text: I didn't disappear. I was gone for a few hours.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: What did you do all day?

dialogues.speaker: JOAN
dialogues.text: I walked around, visited shops.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: You’ve had a cigarette. I can smell it on you.

dialogues.speaker: JOAN
dialogues.text: I stopped at a cafe. It was filled with smoke.  THE WIFE FINAL SHOOTING SCRIPT (16/12/16) 67.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: You’ve been drinking too.

dialogues.speaker: JOAN
dialogues.text: I had a vodka.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: In the middle of the day?

dialogues.speaker: JOAN
dialogues.text: Yes, Joe, in the middle of the day. Joan makes her way through the suite to the master bedroo Joe following.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: You need to pace yourself. You shouldn't be showing up at these functions with alcohol on your breath.

dialogues.speaker: JOAN
dialogues.text: You’re the one who’s the star of the show, why would anyone possibly care?

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: What the hell's gotten into you?

dialogues.speaker: JOAN
dialogues.text: I don't like you lecturing me. I'm not a child. Joe has left his pants and shirt in a heap on the floor. Joan starts picking them up.

dialogues.speaker: JOAN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Dammit, Joe, would you not leave your clothes on the floor? I'm sick of picking up after you.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: Leave it. Here, lemme have it. As Joe grabs his pants from Joan the walnut falls out of pocket.

dialogues.speaker: JOAN
dialogues.text: What's that? Joe moves in, picks it up.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: I was hungry, I bought some walnuts.

dialogues.speaker: JOAN
dialogues.text: Let me see it.  THE WIFE FINAL SHOOTING SCRIPT (16/12/16) 68.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: Come on, Joanie.

dialogues.speaker: JOAN
dialogues.text: Let me see it. Joan grabs at the walnut. Joe tries to keep it away. They wrestle over it like a couple of ten-year-olds.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: What're you doing? You're acting crazy. Joan pries the walnut out of Joe's hand. She stares at th half-completed inscription.

dialogues.speaker: JOAN
dialogues.text: So while I was out being the drunken lush, you, the picture of sobriety, were seducing the luscious young Linnea.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: Nothing happened. Joan hurls the walnut at Joe. It hits him smack in the middle of his forehead.

dialogues.speaker: JOE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Ow! Jesus, Joanie.

dialogues.speaker: JOAN
dialogues.text: Don't insult my intelligence, don't you dare.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: Nothing happened! I was the one who stopped it.

dialogues.speaker: JOAN
dialogues.text: Well bully for you.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: Yes bully for me! You know why I stopped? Because I was thinking about you sitting on some fucking tour bus, feeling neglected, with no one to talk to and I rushed back here so you wouldn't be sitting here all alone! And then I end up waiting for you!

dialogues.speaker: JOAN
dialogues.text: So sorry, Joe, I should've let you know I'd be late so you could finish screwing your photographer.  THE WIFE FINAL SHOOTING SCRIPT (16/12/16) 69.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: I wasn't going to screw her, God dammit. I’m not even attracted to the fucking woman. In fact all I could think about was getting back to you.

dialogues.speaker: JOAN
dialogues.text: I'm touched. The phone is ringing.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: You think I'm proud of my behavior? It sickens me. I’m too old for this shit! I’m done! I’m all yours.

dialogues.speaker: JOAN
dialogues.text: Well goody for me. Joan picks up the phone.

dialogues.speaker: JOAN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (into phone) Hello?

dialogues.speaker: SUSANNAH, (ON PHONE)
dialogues.text: Hi Mom.

dialogues.speaker: JOAN
dialogues.text: Susannah.

dialogues.speaker: SUSANNAH, (ON PHONE)
dialogues.text: I had the baby.

dialogues.speaker: JOAN
dialogues.text: Oh! Joe! Susannah had her baby!

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: Oh my God!

dialogues.speaker: JOAN
dialogues.text: Get on the other line! Joe runs to the library and grabs the phone by the toilet

dialogues.speaker: JOAN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Oh Sweetie, when did this happen?

dialogues.speaker: SUSANNAH, (ON PHONE)
dialogues.text: A couple of hours ago. I’m looking at him right now. He’s beautiful. Mark is holding him. He’s making little mewling sounds.  THE WIFE FINAL SHOOTING SCRIPT (16/12/16) 70.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: It’s a boy?! You had a boy?! What’d you name him?

dialogues.speaker: SUSANNAH ON PHONE
dialogues.text: Max.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: Who does he look like?

dialogues.speaker: SUSANNAH ON PHONE
